title: How to Repair a Deck

methods.name: Inspecting the Deck and Making Minor Repairs

steps.headline: Plan to rebuild the deck if it has significant structural damage.
steps.description: Look closely at any joists, posts, or stair supports that directly contact the ground because these are most likely to have problems with moisture and rot. Poke the tip of a screwdriver into them and see if it sinks in to determine if there is any major structural rot that compromises the stability of the deck.Tip: If you don’t find any rot in the joists or posts that support the deck, but the deck has stairs that are rotting, you can just build a new set of stairs rather than doing a full renovation or replacement. If the tip of the screwdriver sinks into any major support joists or posts, then you will need to get a deck building contractor to do some major renovations or you can rebuild the deck yourself.

steps.headline: Reinforce damaged joists by doubling them up.
steps.description: Cut a new joist to the same dimensions as the existing damaged joist and cover both joists in waterproof sealer. Attach the new joist flush against the damaged joist with 3 in (7.6 cm) decking screws or galvanized nails every 2 ft (0.61 m). Nail or screw the ends of the new joist to the ledger board by putting 2 nails or screws in at an angle. The ledger board is the board at the edge of the deck to which the joists are fastened. The waterproof sealer will prevent the damaged joist from deteriorating more and keep the new joist from rotting due to moisture.

steps.headline: Inspect the deck’s surface for broken boards that need to be replaced.
steps.description: Do a thorough walk-over of the entire surface of the deck and look for boards that are cracked, rotting, or damaged in other ways. Mark the boards that need to be replaced with chalk or a paint marker. It’s important to deal with broken boards promptly so the problem doesn’t get worse. It can be dangerous to continue using a deck with boards that are deteriorating.

steps.headline: Replace any nails that are popping out with 3 in (7.6 cm) decking screws.
steps.description: Look for nails that are sticking up from boards as you inspect the surface of the deck for broken boards. Pry them out with the backside of a hammer and replace them with 3 in (7.6 cm) decking screws using an electric drill. Screws don’t pop out like nails do, so you will avoid this problem in the future by replacing loose nails with decking screws. If the loose nails are on damaged boards that need to be fixed anyways, you don’t need to replace them with screws.

steps.headline: Tighten any hardware that fastens the deck to the building.
steps.description: Inspect the perimeter of the deck anywhere that it is attached to the building and look for loose screws or bolts in the hardware. Use a screwdriver or wrench to tighten any loose screws or bolts you find in the hardware. For example, check any metal joist hangers underneath the deck that you can access.

steps.headline: Stabilize any wobbly sections of railing by tightening screws and bolts.
steps.description: Walk along any sections of railing and gently shake the railing to see if it is stable. Check the bolts and screws that hold the railing in place on any wobbly sections and tighten up any loose bolts or screws. If all the screws and bolts are tight, but the railing is still wobbly, you can drill 1-2 new bolt holes in each railing post and secure them with extra bolts. If that doesn’t fix the problem, or if the railing has any other significant damage, consider redoing the railing.

steps.headline: Pull the fasteners out of damaged boards that you want to replace.
steps.description: Use the back of a hammer or a pry bar to pull any nails out of damaged boards. Unscrew any screws holding broken boards in place using an electric drill with the appropriate screwdriver head attachment. If there are any nails that are particularly hard to pull out, you can place a scrap piece of wood under the back of the hammer or pry bar to provide extra leverage. If there are a lot of boards that need to be replaced, start removing the boards closest to the home first and work your way outwards.

steps.headline: Pry up the damaged deck boards gently and lift them out.
steps.description: Use a pry bar to gently leverage up the broken boards after you have removed the fasteners. Grab them with your hands when they are high enough to do so and pull them all the way out. Be careful not to damage the boards around the sides of the ones you are removing. If you need to use a lot of force to pry them out, then you can put a soft rag or a scrap of wood underneath the pry bar to protect the boards underneath.

steps.headline: Measure the empty spaces for the new boards.
steps.description: Use a tape measure to measure the length of each space where you removed a board. Write down the length of each replacement board you need. If you removed any boards at the side of the deck that have angled cuts, add about 6 in (15 cm) to the length of the replacement boards so they will hang off the side and you can just trim them to fit after installing them.

steps.headline: Cut the new boards to length.
steps.description: Put on safety glasses and ear protection. Use a circular saw or table saw to cut the replacement boards to the lengths that you need. Most decks require 2x4s for the surface. However, make sure you use the same size of boards as the ones that you removed. Try to match the wood type and color to the existing boards. The new boards will still stand out because they haven’t been exposed to the elements, but once you clean and stain the deck they will blend in better.

steps.headline: Secure the replacement boards in place with 3 in (7.6 cm) decking screws.
steps.description: Drop each replacement board into place. Screw 2 3 in (7.6 cm) decking screws through each end into the joist that it rests on.Tip: If you don’t want to use screws because the existing boards are fixed by nails and you prefer the replacement boards to match, then use galvanized ring shank nails to secure the boards in place. If you have any replacement boards at the edges of the deck that are hanging off the sides and require angled cuts, you can now trim them with a circular saw using the boards next to them as a guide rail for the blade of the saw.

steps.headline: Power wash the deck to remove any loose finish, dirt, and stains.
steps.description: Start at 1 side of the deck and aim the power washer down and away from you at about a 45-degree angle. Turn the power washer on and swing the jet stream from side to side as you slowly walk forward along the deck. Pay special attention to any areas that look extra dirty, stained, or have old finish peeling up.Tip: It’s a good idea to check the forecast before you start this process and make sure you have a few clear, dry days. You will need to let the deck dry several times at different stages, so the whole job will go a lot faster if the weather is good. You can rent a power washer at many home improvement centers or power tool stores.

steps.headline: Let the deck dry completely.
steps.description: Wait at least 1 day for the deck to dry out after power washing it. It might take several days, depending on the weather and how hot it is. You need the deck to dry before you apply a deck cleaner so that the wood can actually absorb the cleaner and let it do its job.

steps.headline: Work a deck cleaner into the deck with a stiff-bristled brush.
steps.description: Use a cleaning solution specifically made for cleaning decks. Follow the instructions to dilute it with water, then apply it to the deck with a stiff-bristled brush, working in sections and scrubbing it in well as you go. You can get a deck cleaner at a home improvement center. Make sure you follow any additional instructions for the specific cleaner you buy. Some may require you to dampen the deck before applying it, for instance.

steps.headline: Rinse the cleaner off with a hose as you go.
steps.description: Don’t let any sections of the cleaner dry on the deck. Wait 10-15 minutes after applying the cleaner to a section, then rinse it off thoroughly by spraying it down with a hose. Rinse off any nearby plants when you are done as well to make sure they don’t have any deck cleaner sitting on them.

steps.headline: Wait until the deck is completely dry again.
steps.description: Let the deck dry for at least 1 day or longer, depending on the weather. You need it to be completely dry before staining and sealing it. If you don’t wait for the deck to dry before staining it, the stain won’t bond well and it can even just wash off after it gets rained on a few times.

steps.headline: Apply 1-2 new coats of stain to the entire deck.
steps.description: Choose semi-transparent stain so the old wood has a more uniform color and the new wood blends in better. Use a 2 in (5.1 cm) paint brush to apply stain around the edges of the deck and to any more complicated parts, such as railings. Use a paint roller to apply the stain to the larger surface areas. You can use whatever width of roller is most comfortable and efficient for you. Heavy-duty rollers work best because they will push the stain down into the cracks between deck boards better.
